Jian 343100 China dJiangxi Xintai Functional Materials Technology Co., Ltd., Jian 343100, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Nano-Au has a good catalytic activity for CO oxidation, but its catalytic mechanism is still not clear. Here, CO oxidation on Au2O3 and its thermal decomposition products were studied using thermogravimetric-mass spectrometry (TG-MS) and operando diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy-mass spectrometry (DRIFTS-MS) to explore the key active components of Au catalyst for CO oxidation. The TG-MS results showed that Au2O3 decomposed to AuO at 210 °C and Au at 375 °C and was oxidized to form Au oxide above 375 °C. When Au2O3 decomposed into AuxOy (x>y) above 210 °C, the CO oxidation activity obviously increased. Au atoms in the Au-Au system serve as electron donor and CO adsorption sites. Au atom is oxidized to AuO by the O atom from O2 decomposition following the Epling-Xu decomposition mechanism. A schematic diagram of the key components of Au2O3 catalysts during CO oxidation was proposed based on TG-MS and operando DRIFTS-MS analysis results. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Au2O3 Decomposition products CO catalytic oxidation TG-MS Operando DRIFTS-MS Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Gold (Au) was generally considered to be inert [1], till Haruta et al. discovered that Au nanoparticles can be very active heterogeneous catalysts, catalysis via Au-based systems has become one of the most important topics in the field of heterogeneous catalysis [2–4]. For example, Au-based catalysts can completely convert CO at room temperature or even lower temperatures, which is particularly useful for automatic exhaust gas cleaning [5,6], breathing masks [7,8], H2 fuel purification [9,10], and other aspects of CO purification [4]. The catalytic activity of Au-based catalysts is affected by many factors such as the support, nanoparticle size, valence state, and preparation method, which make the catalytic mechanism of Au-based catalysts quite complex [11]. For example, Li et al. studied CO oxidation on Au/FeOx catalysts using in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and Raman spectrometry and showed that the surface lattice oxygen of FeOx directly participated in CO oxidation at low temperatures [12]. Daniells et al. used a combined Mössbauer, FTIR, and temporal analysis of products (TAP) reactor to study CO oxidation on Au/Fe2O3 and proposed that surface OH played an important role in increasing the CO oxidation rate [13]. Gates et al. studied the active state of Au supported on MgO and proposed that the catalytic activity mainly comes from the positively charged Au [14]. Based on the in situ FTIR analysis of the active sites for CO oxidation on the Au/SBA-15 catalyst, Cutrufelo et al. proposed that the metal cation is the active site [15]. Qian et al. found that the low-coordination Au atoms on Au nanoparticles with bulk Au electronic structure are the active sites during low-temperature CO oxidation on Au/SiO2 catalysts [16]. Although the use of Au-based catalysts has been widely reported, the mechanism of Au-based catalysts is still unclear. The characterization of the physical phase and surface structure of the catalysts before, during, and after the reaction can help to fundamentally understand the reaction performance and stability of the catalysts. Therefore, a characterization technique is urgently needed to probe the mechanism of Au action and to provide a basis for the design of efficient Au-based catalysts. Operando diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (operando DRIFTS) can monitor the changes of surface functional groups on the catalyst under real reaction conditions and has been widely used to investigate catalytic reaction mechanisms. Wu et al. used in situ plasma DRIFTS to study the mechanism of toluene plasma-catalytic oxidation on Au/γ-Al2O3 and found that Au-based catalysts can promote by-product oxidation and surface carbonate gasification [17]. Wang et al. used in situ DRIFTS to study the mechanism of CO adsorption and oxidation and found that mCeO2NR has excellent CO adsorption capacity related to the strong CO adsorption mode of polydentate formed by NaBH4 corrosion [18]. Xu et al. used H2 as a probe molecule to study the formation and disappearance mechanism of oxygen species on the surface of β-MnO2 through operando DRIFTS [19]. They found that the O2 molecule simultaneously decomposes into terminal-type oxygen and bridge-type oxygen as proposed by Epling et al [20]. Here, we refer to the O2 decomposition on a metal oxide as Epling-Xu decomposition. Due to its high infrared extinction coefficient, CO is often used as a probe molecule for operando DRIFTS studies [21]. Jang et al. quantified a part of the catalytic active sites on PdOx by in situ DRIFTS using CO as a probe molecule to further elucidate the surface reconstitution of Pt-Pd bimetallic particles during the reaction [22]. Zhang et al. combined CO molecular probes with FTIR and confirmed that Rh atoms were dispersed on Al2O3 and TiO2 [23]. Furthermore, CO catalytic oxidation is a hot topic. Among them, atomically dispersed metals have been extensively studied in CO oxidation. Hülsey et al. successfully dispersed Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, and Pt atoms on phosphomolybdenum acid to compare the activities of different atoms to disperse metals for CO catalytic oxidation [24]. Ding et al. dispersed Pt monatomic on four oxide supports for CO catalytic oxidation by flame spray pyrolysis, and found that Pt SACs have excellent catalytic performance for CO oxidation [25]. Therefore, the CO oxidation was chosen to be more suitable to study the catalytic oxidation mechanism of Au-based catalysts by operando DRIFTS technique. In order to investigate the effect of Au on CO oxidation, this work evaluated the catalytic mechanism of CO oxidation on Au2O3 using pure Au2O3 as the raw component. The study of Au2O3 mainly focused on its thermal stability and intermediate valence states. Ono et al. studied the effect of particle size and support on the thermal stability of Au2O3 using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The results showed that the stability varies with the average particle size and the properties of oxide support [26]. Szlachetko et al. determined the real-time reaction intermediates of Au2O3 in H2 reduction using resonant inelastic X-ray scattering (RIXS) spectroscopy, and found that Au2O is an unstable intermediate in temperature-programmed reduction [27]. Few studies have focused on the CO oxidation on Au2O3 or the decomposition components of Au2O3. Herein, Au2O3 and its decomposition products were selected to investigate the key components that could catalyze CO oxidation using thermogravimetric and mass spectrometry (TG-MS) and operando DRIFTS-MS. Au2O3 and its decomposition products were characterized using X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman spectrometry, FTIR, scanning electron microscope (SEM), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), and H2 temperature-programmed reduction DRIFTS-MS (H2-TPR-DRIFTS-MS). The mechanism of CO oxidation was proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Au2O3 was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Company of China with 99.9% purity. 2.2 Evaluation of CO oxidation activity CO oxidation activity was evaluated using a fixed-bed flow reactor filled with 100 mg (40-60 mesh) Au2O3 powder operating at atmospheric pressure. The reactor was supplied with a gas mixture of 1 vol.% CO and 20 vol.% O2 balanced with N2 at 100 mL/min, corresponding to a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 60,000 mL/g/h. CO and CO2 concentrations in the gas mixture from the inlet and outlet of the reactor were analyzed online using a gas chromatograph (GC9790 II, Fuli, China). CO conversion and CO2 selectivity were calculated as follows: (1) CO conversion ( % ) = [ CO ] in − [ CO ] out [ CO ] in × 100 (2) CO 2 selectivity ( % ) = [ C O 2 ] out [ CO ] in × 100 here, [ CO ] in and [ CO ] out are the CO concentrations in the inlet and outlet gas mixtures of the reactor, respectively. [ C O 2 ] out is the CO2 concentration in the outlet gas mixture of the reactor. 2.3 Catalyst characterization XRD (Rigaku Ultimate IV, Japan) was used to measure the crystal property of Au2O3. The radiation wavelength was 0.154 nm, and the scanning speed was 5°/min; a SEM (Hitachi Regulus 8100, Japan) was used to observe the morphologies of Au2O3 and its decomposition products. HRTEM (FEI Talos F200x G2, USA) was used to observe lattice changes before and after the Au2O3 reaction. The valence states of Au2O3 before and after the reaction were characterized using XPS (Thermo Scientific K-Alpha, USA). The Au2O3 structure and defects were analyzed using Raman spectrometry (HORIBA Scientific LabRAM HR Evolution, Japan). FTIR (Nicolet 50, Thermo Scientific, USA) was applied to observe the structure of Au2O3. The H2 reduction of Au2O3 was characterized using the H2-TPR-DRIFTS-MS (DRIFTS: Nicolet 50, Thermo Scientific, USA; MS: Tilon, LC-D200M, Ametek, USA). The experimental procedure was as follows: (1) Ar was purged to MS baseline becoming stable. (2) About 125 mg catalyst powder was added to the catalyst cell and purged with Ar gas for 30 min to remove residual air. The background spectrum was automatically collected using the built-in software. A gas mixture of 1 vol.% H2 with Ar balance was introduced at 37 mL/min for 20 min, and the cell temperature was then elevated from 25 °C to 500 °C with a ramp of 10 °C/min. The spectra were recorded with 32 overlapping scans at a resolution of 4 cm‒1. (3) The gases from the catalyst cell were monitored using the MS. The decomposition of Au2O3 was performed in a thermogravimetric mass spectrometry (TG-MS) (LABSYS evo TGA, Setaram, France; MS: Tilon, LC-D200M, Ametek, USA); here 10.43 mg of Au2O3 was heated from 25 °C to 900 °C with a ramp of 10 °C/min in a gas atmosphere (1 vol.% CO, 20 vol.% O2, Ar balance) at 100 mL/min. The gas from the TG was analyzed online using the MS. Operando DRIFTS-MS was used to observe the changes of functional groups on Au2O3 surface and the concentrations of gaseous products during the reaction of Au2O3 catalyzed oxidation of CO. The operando DRIFTS consisted of an infrared spectrometer (Nicolet 50, Thermo Scientific, USA) with a MCT-A detector and catalyst cell. The temperature of the catalyst cell was controlled using a controller (HVC-DRP-5, Harrick, USA). About 125 mg catalyst powder was added to the catalyst cell, purged with Ar gas for 30 min to remove residual air, and the background spectrum was automatically collected. After a gas mixture of CO, O2, and Ar was introduced at 37 mL/min for 20 min, the cell temperature was elevated from 25 °C to 500 °C with a ramp of 10 °C/min, and the spectra were recorded with 32 overlapping scans at a resolution of 4 cm‒1. The gaseous composition after CO oxidation on Au2O3 in the catalyst cell was monitored using the MS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 CO oxidation activity CO oxidation activity was evaluated (Fig. 1 a). At 25 °C, CO conversion and CO2 selectivity were 12% and 93%, respectively, indicating that Au2O3 had a catalytic effect on promoting CO oxidation at 25 °C. The CO conversion was obviously increased when the temperature was higher than 250 °C, suggesting that Au2O3 decomposition product enhanced the CO oxidation. CO conversion increased and peaked at 25% (at 100 °C) when the temperature was below 250 °C, possibly due to the difference in carbonate accumulation, this finding could be proved from the fact that CO2 selectivity was less than 100%. Fig. 1b illustrates that CO2 MS signal from the Au2O3 (after 1-h CO oxidation at 25 °C) during heating from 25 °C at 10 °C/min to 600 °C with Ar gas. CO2 MS signal had peaks at 78, 130, 240, 470, and 540 °C, confirming the presence of carbonates on the Au2O3 as the carbonates can be gasified into gaseous CO2 by heating to a high temperature. The carbonates have binding types of symmetrical, monodentate, bidentate, and bridged/polydentate; the carbonate bindings at metal oxide surfaces are influenced by such as the charge distribution [28], resulting in different accumulation and gasification characteristics that affect the release of CO oxidation active sites. 3.2 CO oxidation on thermal decomposition products of Au2O3 The thermal decomposition of Au2O3 was studied using the TG (Fig. 2 a). The mass of Au2O3 decreased with three different decomposition stages from Au2O3 to Au0 within a temperature range from 25 to 375 °C. The first inflection point occurred at 210 °C and the weight decreased from 100% to 96.0%, during which Au2O3 was decomposed to AuO with a theoretical weight remaining of 96.4% [29]. The second inflection point was located at 285 °C above which the weight decreased rapidly. The lowest weight remaining was 89.1%, which corresponded to a weight loss of Au2O3 to Au [29]. The results showed that Au2O3 was completely decomposed to Au at 375 °C. The weight increased and saturated to a level of about 89.8% due to the oxidation of Au surface to Au oxide [30,31]. The MS signals of CO, CO2, and O2 are illustrated in Fig. 2b. CO and O2 MS signals decreased, but CO2 MS signal did not change when the temperature was below 190 °C, this fact implied that CO was oxidized but the gaseous CO2 formation was not enhanced. It must be noted that the base level of CO2 MS signal was around 2.85 × 10‒9 without CO oxidation. CO2 MS signal was at a level of 2.92 × 10‒9 with CO oxidation below 190 °C. The CO MS signal began to decrease and that of CO2 began to increase when the temperature was higher than 190 °C at which Au2O3 was partially decomposed to AuO. The MS signals of CO and CO2 changed remarkedly at a temperature higher than 210 °C within which Au2O3 was completely decomposed to AuO and a part of AuO was decomposed into AuxOy (x > y). The O2 MS signal had a similar variation with CO. This fact implied that AuxOy (x > y) had catalytic effect on CO oxidation above 210 °C. The MS signals of CO and CO2 became stable at temperatures higher than 400 °C. These findings clearly showed that AuxOy (x>y) had a stable catalytic effect on CO oxidation at temperatures above 400 °C. The TG-MS results in Figs. 2a and 2b show that the lower CO conversion (Fig. 1a) at room temperature is associated with Au2O3; the +3 valence Au plays a role but not a significant one. The abrupt change in catalytic activity above 210 °C and the basic stability above 400 °C are associated with AuxOy (x > y), which is mainly present as Au+ and Au0 above 210 °C. This suggests that Au+ and Au0 play a major role in CO oxidation. To further verify this conclusion, a series of characterization steps of the physical phases and surface chemical structures of the catalysts are presented below. 3.3 Physical phase characterization The XRD pattern of Au2O3 is shown in Fig. 3 . Au2O3 mainly exposed crystal planes such as (4 2 0) and (4 2 2), which complied with the standard card JCPDS-43-1039. The grain size of Au2O3 was 1.5 nm calculated with Scherrer's formula D=kλ/βcosθ. This is shown in Table 1 . The SEM and HRTEM images of fresh Au2O3 are shown in Figs. 4 a and 4e. The Au2O3 spheres had a diameter from 0.31 nm to 350 nm. Clear lattice fringes could be observed using the HRTEM (Fig. 4f). According to the JCPDS-43-1039 standard, the lattice distances of 0.31 and 0.32 nm belong to the (8 0 0) and (4 2 2) crystal planes, respectively. This result is also consistent with the XRD data (Fig. 3). The grain size of Au2O3 was 1.5 nm calculated with the Scherrer's formula. The JCPDS-43-1039 standard suggests that the lattice distance was 0.28 nm (Fig. 4h) and was assigned to the (2 2 2) crystal plane. The fresh Au2O3 spheres were fixed in the reactor, and the reaction gas (1 vol% CO, 20 vol% O2, and N2 balance) was introduced to evaluate the CO oxidation at different temperatures up to 200, 400, and 600 °C. The decomposition products of Au2O3 were collected and used for HRTEM and SEM characterization. When Au2O3 was decomposed to Au with surface Au oxide from 25 °C to 600 °C, the particle size changed from several 10s nm (Figs. 1a-1c) to 7 μm (Fig. 4d), suggesting that a significant agglomeration of Au particles occurred above 400 °C, thus resulting in the formation large particles with a micrometer size. This may be the reason for the reduced activity of the catalyst at 600 °C (Fig. 1). 3.4 Surface chemical structures The XPS spectra of O 1s are shown in Fig. 5 a. The peaks at 530, 531, and 535.3 eV correspond to the oxygen species of lattice oxygen (Olatt), adsorbed oxygen (Oads), and surface hydroxyl group (OOH), respectively [4,19,32]. The peak areas of oxygen species before and after the CO oxidation were used to quantify the ratios of Olatt/(OOH+Oads+Olatt) and Oads/(OOH+Oads+Olatt) (Table 1). The Olatt/(OOH+Oads+Olatt) ratio before CO oxidation was 0.31, which is higher than that (0.16) after CO oxidation suggesting that O atoms in Au-O-Au were reduced to form oxygen vacancies (Au-□-Au) or Au-Au. The Oads/(OOH+Oads+Olatt) ratio before CO oxidation was 0.57, which is less than that after CO oxidation (0.75) due to the oxidation of Au to form surface Au oxide because the CO oxidation occurred up to 600 °C, which is higher than the 375 °C for surface Au oxidation (Fig. 2). According to the literature [30,31] and TG-MS results, we speculate that Au can promote the dissociation of O2 and form the Au oxide containing O-Au-O structure on its surface under the high temperature conditions. The XPS spectra of Au 4f are shown in Fig. 5b. The peaks at 83.5, 84.2, and 86.3 eV before CO oxidation correspond to Au0, Au+, and Au3+, respectively [4,32-35]. The peak area ratios of Au3+/(Au0+Au++Au3+) before and after CO oxidation are shown in Table 1. Au3+/(Au0+Au++Au3+) ratio before CO oxidation was 0.81 suggesting that the valence state of Au existed mainly in the form of +3 valence in Au2O3. After CO oxidation at 600 °C, the Au0/(Au0+Au++Au3+) ratio increased from 0 (in Au2O3) to 0.98, the Au+/(Au0+Au++Au3+) ratio decreased from 0.19 to 0.02, and no Au3+ was found. Combined with the remarkable increase in CO conversion on thermal decomposition products of Au2O3 (Fig. 2a), these results suggest that Au0 and Au+ dominated CO oxidation. The Raman spectrum of Au2O3 is shown in Fig. 5c. The peaks at 427.2 and 448–774 cm‒1 were attributed to the telescopic vibrations of Au-O and Au-O-Au bonds, respectively [36,37]. The peak areas of Au-O (S Au-O) and Au-O-Au (S Au-O-Au) were calculated using LabSpec [38]. The ratio of S Au-O-Au/(S Au-O+ S Au-O-Au) was 0.84 (Table 1) suggesting indicating that Au2O3 was composed of a Au-O-Au structure in bulk phase. The Au=O was the main oxygen species on Au2O3 surface. The FTIR spectrum of Au2O3 is shown in Fig. 5d. The absorption peaks at 3453 and 1636 cm‒1 were attributed to OH vibration [39,40] and H2O vibration [39], respectively. The peaks at 996 and 553 cm‒1 were assigned to the vibration of Au-O [41,42] and Au-O-Au [42] bonds, respectively. The peak area ratio of SAu-O-Au/(SAu-O +SAu-O-Au) was 0.86 (Table 1), which is consistent with the Raman spectrometry results. 3.5 Reducibility of Au2O3 intermediates The thermal decomposition characteristics and structural features of Au2O3 were characterized using GC (Fig. 1a), TG-MS (Figs. 2a and 2b), and Raman (Fig. 5c). The active sites for CO oxidation above 200 °C were mainly Au+ and Au0. Immediately after, we performed an in-depth analysis of the catalyst by H2-TPR-DRIFTS-MS to investigate the intermediates of the Au2O3 catalyst in terms of the valence. The H2-TPR-DRIFTS-MS spectra are shown in Fig. 6 . The H2-TPR MS signal (m/z = 2) had three negative peaks around 25–150, 183–217, and 281–425 °C (Fig. 6c). Three positive peaks of H2O MS signal (m/z = 18) were observed within 41.5–200, 200–260, and 260–500 °C. The O2 (m/z = 32) showed two positive peaks in the rages of 39.5–130 and 160–222 °C. The MS signals of H2, O2 and H2O below 260 °C were significantly correlated. H2O was produced from the oxidation of H2 where O atoms from Au2O3 decomposition. The temperature range in which the H2O peak appears is basically consistent with the O atoms released by the thermal decomposition process. The result indicates that the O species in the intermediates of Au2O3 catalyst migrate during the H2 reduction process. It also indicates that the catalyst has good reduction performance. Au2O3 thermal decomposition yields excessive O atoms that combine with each other to form O2. This fact supports the findings of Szlachetko et al. who found that Au2O3 begins to decrease at around 80 °C. An unstable and trace intermediate Au2O was found at 80–200 °C. The concentration of Au0 increased rapidly at 180–220 °C and was reduced to Au0 at 300 °C [27]. An operando DRIFTS study was conducted to further analyze the migration of oxygen species in different intermediates (Fig. 6a). Negative peaks associated with OH (3300 cm‒1) [19], H2O (1650 cm‒1) [19], Au=O (1315 cm‒1) [19], and Au-O-Au (705 cm‒1) [19] could be found in the DRIFTS spectra (Fig. 6a) suggesting that the surface substances related to these peaks decreased during H2 reduction duration. The peak heights of Au=O and Au-O-Au are shown in Fig. 6b. The peak height of Au-O-Au was negative between 25 and 300 °C but increased above 300 °C. The Au2O3 decomposes continuously as the temperature increases when the temperature is 25–300 °C (Fig. 2a), which in turn releases oxygen atoms to react with H2. In this temperature range, oxygen atoms from Au-O-Au are mainly released (Fig. 6b). Similar results as in Fig. 1 are seen when the temperature is greater than 300 °C. As Au2O3 decomposes to monolithic gold at 375 °C, the monolithic gold is oxidized to form gold oxides containing Au=O and Au-O-Au structures with increasing temperature. Fig. 6b shows that Au=O and Au-O-Au are consumed above 400 °C. This indicates that, above 300 °C, the oxygen released from Au=O and Au-O-Au mainly reacts with H2. According to the literature [27], the chemical states existed in the catalyst were mainly Au+ and Au0 at 180 °C and above. The results of the H2-TPR-operando DRIFTS show that the main reason for the better reduction performance of Au2O3 is the presence of Au+ and Au0. The H2 negative peak within 25–150 °C and H2O positive peak withing 41.5–200 °C indicated that the O atoms in Au2O3 could oxidize H2 to H2O. Positive O2 MS signal was observed with 39.5–130 °C during which H2 was oxidized. This indicated that O atoms were released during Au2O3 composition. The O atoms could react with H2 to produce H2O or combine to form O2. 3.6 Operando DRIFTS-MS 3.6.1 CO oxidation at 25 °C CO oxidation on Au2O3 with and without O2 at 25 °C was investigated using the DRIFTS-MS (Fig. 7 ). Peaks at 2354 (gas phase CO2 [43,44]), 2167 (gas phase CO [33,45,46]), and 2115 cm‒1 (gas phase CO [33,45,46]) could be found. The negative peaks at 1320 and 714 cm‒1 corresponded to Au=O and bridging oxygen (Au-O-Au), respectively [19]. The peak at 1457 cm‒1 was assigned to bicarbonate between 25 and 150 °C [47,48]. This phenomenon was confirmed during 60 min feeding CO gases with or without O2 (Figs. 7a and 7b). Obvious negative Au-O-Au peaks were found during CO oxidation with O2, but these were not obvious without O2. This finding suggested that O2 promoted Au-O-Au consumption. The CO and CO2 MS signals trended to be constant when CO was oxidized with O2 (Fig. 7c). However, the CO MS signal increased and CO2 MS signal decreased when CO oxidation was seen without O2 (Fig. 7d). The O2 MS signal rapidly decreased to a constant level when CO-containing gas was introduced to the reactor when CO was oxidized with O2 (Fig. 7e). These facts suggest that CO could be oxidized by Au2O3, and O2 participated in the CO oxidation. The results show that the Au3+ is not significant for CO oxidation at room temperature. It is possible that carbonate accumulates while Au3+ is covered by active sites due to the lack of covalent electrons limiting the chemisorption capacity [49]. 3.6.2 CO oxidation during heating Fig. 8 a shows DRIFTS spectra of surface oxygen species on Au2O3 during CO oxidation when the temperature was elevated from 25 to 500 °C. The peak positions were consistent with those at room temperatures. The peak at 1457 cm–1 was assigned to bicarbonate between 25 and 150 °C and bidentate carbonate between 300 and 500 °C. Fig. 8b shows the normalized intensities of carbonate, Au=O, and Au-O-Au as a function of reaction temperature. The normalized intensities of carbonate and Au-O-Au decreased to their lowest value at 250 °C and increased with increasing temperature above 250 °C. The normalized intensity of Au=O explored changes contrary to carbonate and Au-O-Au. The MS signals of CO, CO2, and O2 obviously changed around 250 °C. The presence of Au=O, Au-O-Au, and carbonate suggested that the catalytic mechanism of Au is based on Au oxide. Together with the fact that AuxOy (x>y) (Fig. 2), the key component of Au having catalytic effect on CO oxidation is the lattice oxygen in Au-O-Au and surface oxygen at Au-Au=O. The operando DRIFTS-MS characterization data for heating revealed that the catalytic mechanism of Au is like that of transition metal oxide, but a metallic bond (Au-Au) is required, which may because the Au-Au valence can provide bonding electrons for Au-O to generate Au=O. Interestingly, the normalized intensity of carbonate increased obviously when temperature was higher than 200 °C. The MS signals of CO, CO2, and O2 saturate above 300 °C. This carbonate was a bidentate carbonate due to CO2 adsorption on Au=O, which led to the formation of bidentate carbonate. The results show that Au+ and Au0 play an important role in CO oxidation when the temperature is higher than 200 °C. 3.7 Oxygen species migration properties of Au2O3 intermediates CO oxidation on the catalyst generally obeys the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism based on the reaction between adsorbed species. Table 2 summarizes the surface structure of Au oxide, valence state, and possible chemisorption species at Au sites. Au3+ had poor chemisorption ability due to the lack of covalent electrons [49]. Au1+ and Au0+ could adsorb [CO]‒, [OH]‒, O 2 − , O 2 2 − , and O2‒, which were the adsorbed species necessary for CO oxidation. These results illustrate the structural and valence changes in the key components of Au-based catalysts at different temperatures due to changes in the form of Au. Au2O3 functioned as CO oxidation catalyst at room temperature. Based on the results in Figs. 2a and 7, the CO oxidation process could be devised to the following reactions: 1) CO oxidation by terminal-type oxygen (3) Au = O + CO = Au + CO 2 2) CO oxidation by bridge-type oxygen (4) Au − O − Au + CO = ( OC ) Au − O − Au (5) ( OC ) Au − O − Au = Au − □ − Au + CO 2 3) O2 decomposition (Epling-Xu decomposition) (6) O 2 + Au − □ − Au = O = Au − O − Au Au2O3 could be decomposed by heating and releasing O atoms, which can oxidize H2 near room temperature. The TG results (Figs. 2a and 2b) indicated that AuxOy (x>y) obtained when Au2O3 decomposition above 210 °C had a higher catalytic activity for CO oxidation than Au2O3 below 200 °C because CO oxidation follows L-H mechanism and CO adsorption is an important step to initiate oxidation. This means that the Au catalyst should have sites capable for CO adsorption. O2 activation on the Au catalyst is also important. The Au=O and Au-O-Au are present during CO oxidation up to 500 °C (DRIFTS-MS) and 900 °C (TG-MS), respectively. the O2 decomposition was explored to obey the similar role on metal oxide as Epling-Xu decomposition mechanism (Eq. 6), which was proposed by Epling et al. [20] and confirmed by Xu et al. [19]. Fig. 9 illustrates the mechanisms of CO oxidation and O2 decomposition on Au catalyst at room temperature (Fig. 9a) and a temperature (higher than 210 °C) (Fig. 9b). At room temperature, the CO first reacts with Au=O to form CO2 and then reacts with the O atom in Au-O-Au to form CO2 and Au-□-Au, following the Marsevan Krevelen (MVK) mechanism, since CO2 can easily desorb due to the facile cleavage of either a Au-O or Au-C bond reported by Kimble et al. based on an experiment and theory study of CO oxidation [50]. The decomposition of O2 in the presence of oxygen follows the Epling-Xu mechanism. CO oxidation follows the L-H mechanism and the decomposition of O2 also follows the Epling-Xu mechanism above 210 °C. During heating, the catalytic mechanism of Au is similar to that of transition metal oxide, but a metallic bond (Au-Au) is required, which may be because the Au-Au valence can provide bonding electrons for Au-O to generate Au=O. Au-Au=O reacts with gas-phase CO to form CO2, a process that is considered to be the E-R mechanism [51] . 4 Conclusions Exploring the reaction mechanism of Au is particularly important for gold chemistry because the active oxidation state of Au-based catalysts is highly controversial. Most of the active Au states are based on pre- and post-reaction analysis. In contrast, this work characterizes the physical phase and surface structure of the catalyst before, during, and after the reaction by characterization techniques such as operando DRIFTS-MS and TG-MS to reveal the key components of Au-based catalysts during the reaction. The main findings are summarized below. 1) TG-MS results show that Au2O3 has been completely decomposed into elemental Au at 375 °C, while elemental Au will be oxidized to form Au oxides above 375 °C. In addition, the results of TG-MS show that Au+ and Au0 produced during Au2O3 decomposition have catalytic effect. 2) The MS signal results of H2-TPR indicate that Au2O3 undergoes migration of oxygen species in different temperature ranges. Operando DRIFTS results indicate that bridge oxygen (Au-O-Au) and terminal oxygen Au=O undergo migration during the H2 reduction process. The results also show that the main reason for the better reduction performance of Au2O3 is the presence of Au+ and Au0. 3) The DRIFTS-MS-TPR results show that the key components with catalytic effect on CO oxidation are Au+ and Au0. The catalytic mechanism of Au is similarly to that of transition metal oxides. CO oxidation follows the L-H mechanism and the decomposition of O2 also follows the Epling-Xu mechanism above 210 °C. coredata.dc:description: Nano-Au has a good catalytic activity for CO oxidation, but its catalytic mechanism is still not clear. Here, CO oxidation on Au2O3 and its thermal decomposition products were studied using thermogravimetric-mass spectrometry (TG-MS) and operando diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy-mass spectrometry (DRIFTS-MS) to explore the key active components of Au catalyst for CO oxidation. The TG-MS results showed that Au2O3 decomposed to AuO at 210 °C and Au at 375 °C and was oxidized to form Au oxide above 375 °C. When Au2O3 decomposed into AuxOy (x>y) above 210 °C, the CO oxidation activity obviously increased. Au atoms in the Au-Au system serve as electron donor and CO adsorption sites. Au atom is oxidized to AuO by the O atom from O2 decomposition following the Epling-Xu decomposition mechanism. A schematic diagram of the key components of Au2O3 catalysts during CO oxidation was proposed based on TG-MS and operando DRIFTS-MS analysis results.
coredata.dc:title: Exploring the key components of Au catalyst during CO oxidation using TG-MS and operando DRIFTS-MS
